title: Clive Woodward explains why England had try disallowed vs New Zealand
text:
Sam Underhill appeared to have added five more points but his try was wiped out (Picture: Getty)

Former England head coach Sir Clive Woodward has backed Nigel Owens’ decision to disallow a try for England in the first half of their Rugby World Cup semi-final against New Zealand.

Eddie Jones’ side made a ferocious start to the match, scoring through Manu Tuilagi in the second minute – the fastest try the All Blacks have ever conceded in the tournament’s history.

They appeared to have bagged a second try thanks to Sam Underhill, but after initially waving play on, referee Owens pulled the play back and awarded a penalty to New Zealand.

Tuilagi gave England a blistering start in Japan on Saturday (Picture: AP)

‘It was correct. It was interesting Nigel Owen didn’t rule it initially,’ said Woodward on ITV during half-time.

‘We get really quick ball. The key guy is [Tom] Curry, if he can just stay behind [Kyle] Sinckler it’s not going to be a penalty.

‘If he goes in front of him and there’s no contact with the All Blacks players it’s all fine.

‘When we scored our first try I leapt up but I didn’t on this occasion. There was just too big a gap so something had happened.

‘To be fair the referee didn’t panic, got the right call from the TMO but it was so close. If he had just stayed behind the ball it’s a try.’

Tom Curry ran ahead of Sinckler to create the opening for Underhill (Picture: ITV)

England did manage to add three more points just before half-time through the boot of George Ford but had another try ruled out at the start of the second half, with Owens explaining the decision to skipper Owen Farrell.

‘The TMO has a clear view that he’s in front of him. It is lost by your player, but the guy who gathers it is in front of him, so that’s why we can’t allow the try,’ said the Welsh ref.

‘Owen please listen to my explanation. The TMO has confirmed. The player behind loses control of it and it’s taken by the player in front of him, therefore we cannot allow the try because he’s in front. If he was behind, no issues.’
